title: How do I know what is allowable/reasonable for expenses in Schedule J when filing a Chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: Are the Schedule J expenses the same as the IRS allowable living expense national standards?
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Finances and child support,Determining child support payments,Tax law
answers:
No. List actual living expenses on Schedule J.
IRS guidelines used to calculate Means test.
Excellent responses from colleagues. I agree.
I concur with my colleagues. Schedule J is for your actual expenses.

Schedule J lists your actual expenses, not the numbers the IRS allows when calculating your expenses. The Income and Expense schedule are used to determine your projected net income to show you are filing in good faith. The Means Test uses historical data and the IRS allowances to determine your past income and expenses to determine if you qualify for a chapter 7 or could pay into a chapter 13 plan. In otherwords, the Means Test uses what the government thinks you should spend, based on your income, and the J schedule calculates what you actually spend.

You are supposed to list your actual monthly expenses. What do you normally spend for the various items on Schedule J? Do not underestimate to attempt to look good but do not exaggerate your expenses either.

No, the IRS allowable expenses are not a sacred cow you can rely on for your expenses on Schedule J. You should be using the actual expenses you can document. Remember, every line in your Schedules is considered to be "under penalty of perjury." I know what is allowable and reasonable in my community because I have over 30 years of bankruptcy experience. Hope this perspective helps!

the facts, common sense, life's learnings, your past purchases, etc. All those go into that formula..nothing magical. Allowable is not on that form. You even can add on other expenses as it so provides.

But you must not have met with an experienced attorney yet or you would know..and that is a huge mistake. Meet on on AVVO now..many great ones in CA on Avvo. But other issues and facts can affect any advice to you so I will point out some of those now too.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
No. Schedule J is where you list your real ongoing monthly expenses. Don't forget to include the monthly amount for expenses you pay quarterly or annually, as well.

I agree that schedule J contains your actual expenses, but I'm glad you looked at the IRS standards before filing because I was once at a hearing where Judge Bowie told the debtor in another case, "that may be what you spend, but it is your decision to rent such an expensive apartment and drive such a fancy car. You may have the apartment and the car, but not at the expense of your creditors." in that case, the judge determined there was disposable income that could be used to pay creditors even though there technically wasn't.

I am reading your question and looking at the areas of concern that you listed. It appears that you have tax debt, Student Loan Debt, a DSO, and perhaps some credit card debt. I do not see this as a very easy straight forward Chapter 7 case. For instance, taxes can be very tricky to address in a Chapter 7. Equally, student loan debts are it own area of law. May I suggest you seek the advice of an experienced local San Diego bankruptcy attorney who has specialized knowledge in both the Bankruptcy and Student Loan areas.
